story:
The participation of many people in this funding campaign has helped me with production costs -  the printing of a museum quality, colour edition of the new book, Piercing Time - Paris after Marville and Atget. The fundraising continues now through the store where you can pre-order the book or buy a print. The blog continues to present images and commentary on the project:  http://parisaftermarville.tumblr.com.

Although we met the goal, this is less than half of the funds needed. But... we are on the way there.

Peter Sramek (sramek.ca) has been a photographic artist since the 1970s and has produced many series of black and white photographs related to historic sites in France, Italy, Czech Republic, Germany and in Canada where he lives. He is Chair of Photography at OCAD University and is represented by the Stephen Bulger Gallery (www.bulgergallery.com).

The campaign is specifically to raise the funds which Sramek has committed himself to find in order to keep the final cover price down while producing a large, expensively printed monograph.

What can you do? Begin by spreading the word to your contacts and then donate what you can, to support the project and receive the great 'perks'.

The book is to be published by Intellect Press (www.intellectbooks.co.uk) and released through the University of Chicago Press in the fall of 2013. Production costs will be about $30,000. and financial support is needed for the high quality printing of so many image pages. The historical images will come from new, high resolution digital copywork from the Parisienne de Photographie agency in Paris who have been extremely supportive of this project.

 In his own words:

I am really excited about the many themes which run though this project and I want the book to reflect this in its quality of production. This is probably the most significant body of work I have done to date. It will add to a wide range of fields, opening up the Marville archive in new ways for visitors to Paris as well as scholars of urban studies and photographic history. By bringing in local voices, it will give a window onto how people feel today about urban change and connect this with historical attitudes about development in this key city which brought Europe into the modern age.

Although I need $15,000 in total, this campaign aims modestly to raise a portion of this. If we can actually get to our ultimate goal, then I can move forward with our vision of high quality printing without cutting corners while still keeping the final price affordable.

After 4 years in the making (and nearly 150 years after Marville's photographs) your participation at whatever level you choose is necessary to get this project out into the world as a physical, printed reality. Wouldn't you rather hold this in your hands than simply look at examples on youfr screen? Help us to make this book a reality.

 The Rewards

Although you are being asked to support this project because you are excited about it, the rewards are definitely a bargain. The prints are being offered below value for this limited period, but still as signed and numbered editions. Buying the book ahead of time will give you a signed copy as soon as it is available while giving you images for your desktop right away. Prints will be produced as soon as the campaign ends. Check out further reward details and other images from the project at ParisAfterMarville.tumblr.com.

      

   Rue du Chat-qui-Pêche            Rue du Jour - Eglise St-Eustache

 

      

            Rue de Bièvre                      Rue du Maître-Albert 

Your Support

Whatever you are able to do will be appreciated. Simply buying a copy of the book now, will help make its production possible. Pre-sales are a substantial way to demonstrate the interest in the forthcoming publication and they assure the publisher of sales potential.

And even if you are unable to assist financially, the key to Indiegogo is getting the word out. Your actions are needed to make the campaign a success.

There are many people who are interested in Paris, photography, urban development, old architecture, maps and history. This book will be of interest to them, but only if they know about it.

Please pass this Indiegogo link on to your contact lists;

Subscribe to the blog (ParisAfterMarville.tumblr.com);

Like us on FaceBook (facebook.com/ParisAfterMarville);

Follow our tweets (@AfterMarville);

Reblog and retweet us;

Spread the word.

This Indiegogo page provides easy sharing tools to help you do this.

We will be providing new images and updates on these sites during and after the campaign.

The Team

This is not a commercial project. I have devoted 4 years of time and energy, research, photography and writing, not to mention funds.  Françoise Reynaud and Jean-Baptiste-Woloch at the Musée Carnavalet have generously shared their time and expertise. Min K Lee of Swarthmore College and Shalini Le Gall of NYU Paris have carried out their research and written texts. The travel and photography has been partially supported by OCAD University faculty funding and by a Google Research Award. Four assistants have helped with various aspects – Pat Navarro  and Miko Sramek have assisted with database entry and digital processing. Melissa Clark and Shanon Fujioka are working to design and moderate the social media including this campaign.

In the end, production of a large photo book is very expensive and one just hopes to cover costs. This is a labour of love, of cultural work, which hopes to gain your support.

The Project Details

The book documents 184 street locations of Paris and will be illustrated with almost 500 images – by Charles Marville (1860s-70s), Eugène Atget (early 1900s) and Peter Sramek (present day). Related historical maps will locate the images accurately. Texts have been written by historians Min K Lee and Shalini Le Gall, as well as Peter Sramek and interviews with Parisians will bring in a contemporary popular view of urban change. Historical images are coming from the Musée Carnavalet with whom Sramek has worked closely and also from the Bibliothèque Historique, Bibliothèque Nationale and MOMA (NYC).

Release of the book will coincide with a large exhibition of Marville photographs curated by Sarah Kennel of the National Gallery in Washington. This show will then travel to the Metropolitan Museum in NY, to the Carnavalet in Paris and the National Gallery in Ottawa.

The project is described more fully in the Blog which will feature details of the Perks, more example images and annoucements: ParisAfterMarville.tumblr.com
story_txt:
The participation of many people in this funding campaign has helped me with production costs -  the printing of a museum quality, colour edition of the new book, Piercing Time - Paris after Marville and Atget. The fundraising continues now through the store where you can pre-order the book or buy a print. The blog continues to present images and commentary on the project:  http://parisaftermarville.tumblr.com.
Although we met the goal, this is less than half of the funds needed. But... we are on the way there.
Peter Sramek (sramek.ca) has been a photographic artist since the 1970s and has produced many series of black and white photographs related to historic sites in France, Italy, Czech Republic, Germany and in Canada where he lives. He is Chair of Photography at OCAD University and is represented by the Stephen Bulger Gallery (www.bulgergallery.com).
The campaign is specifically to raise the funds which Sramek has committed himself to find in order to keep the final cover price down while producing a large, expensively printed monograph.
What can you do? Begin by spreading the word to your contacts and then donate what you can, to support the project and receive the great 'perks'.

The book is to be published by Intellect Press (www.intellectbooks.co.uk) and released through the University of Chicago Press in the fall of 2013. Production costs will be about $30,000. and financial support is needed for the high quality printing of so many image pages. The historical images will come from new, high resolution digital copywork from the Parisienne de Photographie agency in Paris who have been extremely supportive of this project.
 In his own words:
I am really excited about the many themes which run though this project and I want the book to reflect this in its quality of production. This is probably the most significant body of work I have done to date. It will add to a wide range of fields, opening up the Marville archive in new ways for visitors to Paris as well as scholars of urban studies and photographic history. By bringing in local voices, it will give a window onto how people feel today about urban change and connect this with historical attitudes about development in this key city which brought Europe into the modern age.
Although I need $15,000 in total, this campaign aims modestly to raise a portion of this. If we can actually get to our ultimate goal, then I can move forward with our vision of high quality printing without cutting corners while still keeping the final price affordable.
After 4 years in the making (and nearly 150 years after Marville's photographs) your participation at whatever level you choose is necessary to get this project out into the world as a physical, printed reality. Wouldn't you rather hold this in your hands than simply look at examples on youfr screen? Help us to make this book a reality.
 The Rewards
Although you are being asked to support this project because you are excited about it, the rewards are definitely a bargain. The prints are being offered below value for this limited period, but still as signed and numbered editions. Buying the book ahead of time will give you a signed copy as soon as it is available while giving you images for your desktop right away. Prints will be produced as soon as the campaign ends. Check out further reward details and other images from the project at ParisAfterMarville.tumblr.com.
      
   Rue du Chat-qui-Pêche            Rue du Jour - Eglise St-Eustache
 
      
            Rue de Bièvre                      Rue du Maître-Albert 
Your Support
Whatever you are able to do will be appreciated. Simply buying a copy of the book now, will help make its production possible. Pre-sales are a substantial way to demonstrate the interest in the forthcoming publication and they assure the publisher of sales potential.
And even if you are unable to assist financially, the key to Indiegogo is getting the word out. Your actions are needed to make the campaign a success.
There are many people who are interested in Paris, photography, urban development, old architecture, maps and history. This book will be of interest to them, but only if they know about it.
Please pass this Indiegogo link on to your contact lists;
Subscribe to the blog (ParisAfterMarville.tumblr.com);
Like us on FaceBook (facebook.com/ParisAfterMarville);
Follow our tweets (@AfterMarville);
Reblog and retweet us;
Spread the word.
This Indiegogo page provides easy sharing tools to help you do this.
We will be providing new images and updates on these sites during and after the campaign.

The Team
This is not a commercial project. I have devoted 4 years of time and energy, research, photography and writing, not to mention funds.  Françoise Reynaud and Jean-Baptiste-Woloch at the Musée Carnavalet have generously shared their time and expertise. Min K Lee of Swarthmore College and Shalini Le Gall of NYU Paris have carried out their research and written texts. The travel and photography has been partially supported by OCAD University faculty funding and by a Google Research Award. Four assistants have helped with various aspects – Pat Navarro  and Miko Sramek have assisted with database entry and digital processing. Melissa Clark and Shanon Fujioka are working to design and moderate the social media including this campaign.
In the end, production of a large photo book is very expensive and one just hopes to cover costs. This is a labour of love, of cultural work, which hopes to gain your support.
The Project Details

Related historical maps will locate the images accurately. Texts have been written by historians Min K Lee and Shalini Le Gall, as well as Peter Sramek and interviews with Parisians will bring in a contemporary popular view of urban change. Historical images are coming from the Musée Carnavalet with whom Sramek has worked closely and also from the Bibliothèque Historique, Bibliothèque Nationale and MOMA (NYC).
Release of the book will coincide with a large exhibition of Marville photographs curated by Sarah Kennel of the National Gallery in Washington. This show will then travel to the Metropolitan Museum in NY, to the Carnavalet in Paris and the National Gallery in Ottawa.
The project is described more fully in the Blog which will feature details of the Perks, more example images and annoucements: ParisAfterMarville.tumblr.com

story:
What is Happy Accidents all about?

In 1997, the four original members of Four Day Weekend decided to break out on our own and take the leap to start our very own improv comedy show, in the heart of Sundance Square, in downtown Fort Worth.  The original goal? - to last 6 weeks doing a mini-run and then pack up our bags on the way to the next adventure.  Then, something funny happened on the way through this limited six-week run; the show became a hit, and it became a hit because of the amazing support of the city of Fort Worth that hosted the show, the "powers that be" at Sundance Square, and an amazing fan base that made it all possible!

One little idea of applying the transformative power of “Yes, And,” combined with the unifying thought that "if we band together we can create anything with positive intention," and the heartfelt belief that "what we come up with together is far better than what we come up with individually" has led to our continued success.  The results have exceeded our wildest expectations!  The power of “Yes, And” helped us manifest a keynote address to the United States Congress, performing for two U.S. Presidents, being awarded the Key to the City of Fort Worth, being named Small Business of the Year in 2014 and becoming Entrepreneurs-In-Residence at TCU’s Neeley School of Business.  And all of this became possible because of two little words:  “Yes, And."

In our new book, Happy Accidents: The Transformative Power of "Yes, And" at Work and in Life, we chronicle this amazing success story and we share how we've used “Yes, And” to transform both our working and personal lives.  For the first time ever, we are giving our amazing fans the behind-the-scenes secrets to our success and, most importantly, we want to share with you all the ways that you can unlock life's opportunities, while enjoying some laughs along the way.  And maybe, just maybe, with your help we can make it a best-seller in the process, because without you none of this would have been possible.

What We Need & What You Get

We want share this book with not only our amazing fans of the show, but with people all over the world who want to be better communicators, better individuals, gain momentum in their careers, and foster a positive culture in their communities.

Levels: 

On an improv budget:  $7  We'll send a digital “Shout out” on the 4DW Happy Accidents Supporter Webpage!

Four Day fans who read good:  $28  If you can read this, you're immediately qualified!  You get a hardback copy of Happy Accidents, a 4DW backstage tour video, and High-4 shout out.

4DW Groupie:  $49  For two friends who done read good, you get 2 Hardback copies of Happy Accidents (Get a book!  GIVE a book!), a backstage tour video, and High-4 shout out. 

4DW Party for Four: $107  (4) Books, a backstage Tour video, and a High-4 shout out

4DW Book Club: $247 (8) Books, a personalized video from the cast, and a digital High-4

4DW Ambassador: $757 (12) Autographed Books, VIP Seating for 12, an exclusive private cocktail party with the Four Day Weekend cast.

4DW Big Brother: $2,747 (50) Books, a catered pre-show dinner onstage with Four Day Weekend Cast, a tour of the backstage greenroom & access to our “quotes wall of fame”. (PLUS 10% Donation, split between Big Brothers Big Sisters of North Texas and the charitable arm of Four Day Weekend Secret Blue Butterfly.) 

FDW Corporate Platinum:  $12,747 (100) books, plus Founder’s Keynote (valued at $15K) for your organization!  (PLUS 10% Donation, split between Big Brothers Big Sisters of North Texas and the charitable arm of Four Day Weekend Secret Blue Butterfly.) 

FDW Private Event:  $24,000 Your Exclusive Night with Four Day Weekend -- Private Show up to 212 people (Valued at $15K) and 212 books plus Open Bar Package. *Bonus, you get 1 4DW improv workshop for your team!  (PLUS 10% Donation, split between Big Brothers Big Sisters of North Texas and the charitable arm of Four Day Weekend Secret Blue Butterfly.) 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please pass along our campaign and mission via social channels or word of mouth!  THANK YOU FOR THE 20 YEARS OF SUPPORT!

story:
About Me

My education includes graduate studies in social work, non-profit management and applied statistics, B.A. degrees in Anthropology and Psychology with a Mathematics minor and certificates in Applied Computer Science and Research. While attending university, I completed an Honors Thesis on personality and social identity factors related to music preferences, a field study on the Autism community in Fort Wayne, IN and worked as a research assistant for the Psychology Department at Indiana University Purdue University-Fort Wayne (IPFW).

I have worked as a mental health professional, business owner and manager, created and managed a community group for individuals with substance use issues and worked as a contract IT professional and freelance writer.

What We Need & What You Get

Funds from this campaign will be utilized for the following expenditures:

- Research-related expenditures, including travel costs, technology (audio and video equipment), etc.

 - Hiring a contract artist and editor.

Any donation of $10 reserves an e-book copy upon completion. Any donation of $15 or more reserves a print copy upon completion.

The Impact

This book seeks to shed light on a group the media has neglected to cover for the most part. My preliminary research has discovered a wide range of individuals taking part in this movement, ranging from tenured university professors to unemployed anarchists. There's a lack of research into anarcho-communist groups, especially current research into the rise of Antifa and related organizations.

story:
Mi nombre es Ángela de la Torre, tengo 23 años y soy una fotógrafa de la provincia de León (España) afincada en Madrid desde hace 5 años.

"YO TE CIELO" nace con el principal objetivo de visibilizar al colectivo LGTBI+ (Lesbianas, Gays, Trans, Bisexuales...) a través de la fotografía.

Desde que llegó a mis manos un breve pero intenso poema de Frida Kahlo titulado "Yo te cielo", entendí el significado del amor verdadero: Un amor que no entiende de sexos, identidades, géneros, etiquetas...

Tras colaborar con el colectivo AWEN LGTBI+ de Astorga, pequeña ciudad de la provincia de León (España), decidí embarcarme en este proyecto que pretende visibilizar los diferentes tipos de relaciones amorosas. Unas relaciones generalmente escondidas en pequeñas ciudades como Astorga o en el medio rural y que pretendo visibilizar a través de este proyecto. Parejas que han decidido visibilizarse con valentía frente a mi cámara. Una decisión difícil y valiente cuando se trata de ciudades pequeñas y pueblos como Astorga, donde desde hace menos de un año que se empezó a visibilizar al colectivo de Lesbianas, Gays, Trans, Bisexuales,...

El proyecto consiste en una serie de fotografías de diferentes relaciones homosexuales, lésbicas, bisexuales, trans, heterosexuales, poliamorosas... La gran mayoría de estas fotografías han sido tomadas a parejas de Astorga y del medio rural Leonés. También he realizado alguna sesión en Madrid, ciudad en la que resido en la actualidad.

Las fotografías reflejan momentos de amor en la más absoluta intimidad. Cuerpos desnudos alejados del bullicio de la sociedad y con una única frontera: la piel. Relaciones retratadas con delicadeza y naturalidad presentadas en blanco y negro.

Tengo como objetivo exponer en Astorga el 25 de Junio de 2016 en el conocido Hotel Gaudí ***, coincidiendo con la celebración del Orgullo LGTB de esta ciudad, y realizar también una exposición en Madrid capital. Me he marcado un objetivo y es conseguir imprimir y exponer un total de 30 fotografías en su correspondiente soporte para poder compartir con vosotrxs la obra completa.

¿Me ayudáis a conseguirlo?

     
 

Debido al alto coste de impresión y soportes fotográficos así como de la cartelería necesito de vuestro mecenazgo para conseguir en 60 días mi principal objetivo: exponer la obra completa (30 fotografías) en la ciudad de Astorga y en Madrid. Los comienzos en el mundo de la fotografía son duros y más para los jóvenes creadores que empezamos a exponer. Por eso necesito de vuestra colaboración como mecenas y patrocinadores de este proyecto para apadrinar cada una de las fotografías que compondrán esta exposición.

A cada unx de vosotrxs que decidáis colaborar y ayudarme a exponer la obra completa os obsequiaré con diferentes recompensas que podéis ver más adelante. 

En el caso de no llegar al objetivo inicial, los fondos se destinarán a imprimir todas las fotografías posibles para las exposiciones y recibiréis vuestra recompensa igualmente. En caso de superar la cifra se buscarán mejores formatos de impresión.


La importancia de tu ayuda

Cada granito de arena importa y tu aportación cuenta mucho ya que de vosotrxs dependerá el número de fotografías que compongan esta exposición. Porque todxs y cada unx de vosotrxs sois esenciales en este proyecto.

Aquí os dejo con diferentes enlaces a prensa. Entrevistas e información que han ido compartiendo diferentes medios sobre "YO TE CIELO":

http://www.diariodeleon.es/noticias/provincia/proyecto-yo-cielo-visibilizara-diversidad-afectiva-sexual_1036031.html

http://www.ileon.com/actualidad/058495/el-amor-tal-como-es-y-sin-barrreras-a-traves-del-objetivo-de-una-fotografa-leonesa

http://leonoticias.com/frontend/leonoticias/Quieres-Ser-Mi-Imagen-vn193310-vst343

http://astorgaredaccion.com/not/10750/-yo-te-cielo-retratos-de-amor/

http://tamtampress.es/2016/01/19/angela-de-la-torre-fotografia-el-amor-lgtbi-en-yo-te-cielo/

http://astorgaredaccion.com/not/10806/-busco-que-quien-no-este-acostumbrado-a-ver-otros-tipos-de-parejas-sepa-que-hay-mas-alla-de-los-muros-de-astorga-/

http://blog.irispeople.com/yo-te-cielo-fotos-por-la-diversidad-lgtbi/


      

 El mayor desafío al que me enfrento es poder imprimir la obra completa, pues todas y cada una de las fotografías que la componen son un pedacito de mí y de todoxs aquellxs que se atrevieron a desnudar su alma y sus sentimientos frente a mi cámara. Pero soy una persona que nunca se rinde y cuando tengo un objetivo peleo por el hasta el final. Vuestra ayuda, al igual que los mecenas que apoyaban a los grandes pintores de la época, es muy importante. No sólo para mí, sino para todo un colectivo que lleva años luchando para conseguir igualdad en derechos y que generalmente es discriminado u ocultado en pequeñas ciudades o pueblos.


Otras formas en las que puedes ayudar

Sé de primera mano que corren tiempos difíciles y cada unx puede aportar en la medida de sus posibilidades. Desde una pequeña aportación, hasta compartiendo y difundiendo esta iniciativa por redes sociales. Todo cuenta. Todos y cada uno de los granitos de arena son importantes y ayudarán a hacer posible este proyecto.

Pero soy una persona que nunca se rinde y cuando tengo un objetivo peleo por el hasta el final. Vuestra ayuda, al igual que los mecenas que apoyaban a los grandes pintores de la época, es muy importante. No sólo para mí, sino para todo un colectivo que lleva años luchando para conseguir igualdad en derechos y que generalmente es discriminado u ocultado en pequeñas ciudades o pueblos.      Otras formas en las que puedes ayudar  Sé de primera mano que corren tiempos difíciles y cada unx puede aportar en la medida de sus posibilidades. Desde una pequeña aportación, hasta compartiendo y difundiendo esta iniciativa por redes sociales. Todo cuenta. Todos y cada uno de los granitos de arena son importantes y ayudarán a hacer posible este proyecto.

story:
We're a group of Wesleyan University students writing, editing, illustrating, and designing long-form writing projects together (each ~50 pages). We're telling lots of different stories and we're asking the larger Wesleyan community (& beyond) to help us share them. Let's meet our fundraising goal and exceed it!


What We Need

In short: to be able to print and distribute our work. Beyond making physical print copies we'll be able to use online publishing tools to send our books anywhere in the world!

Donations will:

  • Aid with printing costs, which could be as much as $423 per project. The more funding we have, the more copies we can print - and higher quality (better ink, more color pages, etc)
  • Fund our small launch event on campus in May (with light refreshments!), where we will celebrate our writers and begin distribution of our books
  • Shipping costs

The Impact of Your Donation

Gorilla Publishing Collective writers will have the rare opportunity to be published as college students! 

Additionally, Wesleyan student artists will have the chance to submit their work to be included in the books as illustrations and visual aids. 

This whole project is really a collaborative effort and we want to show the community what we're capable of creating - written work of the highest caliber supported by dynamic art and design.  

Who You're Helping: The Collective

Marissa Castrigno, Sue Greenblatt, Yael Horowitz, Raphael Linden, Karmenife Paulino, and Kai Wilson 

We have four individual projects, and the fifth will be an anthology of work by members of the St. Vincent De Paul soup kitchen's writers group, compiled by Sue and Yael  

Special thanks to our designer Giorgia Peckman, and to Kate Weiner who is lending her eyes during the editing process

Please Donate & Share!

We appreciate every penny that you give.
If you can't make a donation, the best way to help us is to share this campaign and help us spread the word about our project. Thank you!

story:
Jersey City Slam is a non-profit community group dedicated to enriching the
lives of the citizens of New Jersey by exposing and including them in
the art of performance poetry. Our mission is to give local poets an
opportunity to grow as artists and share their art with their local
communities and perform on a national level.  Jersey City Slam provides workshops and classes on everything from stage presence to poetry submission and publication.

Our organization has sent New Jersey poets to the National Poetry Slam,
Jersey City Slam does not ask the poets to pay for any of these trips. We strive to pay 100% of registration expenses for these tournaments.

Our mission is to give local poets an opportunity to grow as artists and share their art with their local communities and perform on a national level.  Jersey City Slam provides workshops and classes on everything from stage presence to poetry submission and publication.Our organization has sent New Jersey poets to the National Poetry Slam, Jersey City Slam does not ask the poets to pay for any of these trips. We strive to pay 100% of registration expenses for these tournaments.

story:
Margareta Borjesson, Swedish, retired organizational consultant in my own company, 70. Mother, grandmother, ex-wife, elder sister, friend.

 I used to be normal. Live life as expected, love my man, my home and my cat, children and grandchildren. I lost the life I used to have, due to secret netgambling for a couple of years. When my partner asked me to marry him, I was forced to tell him everything. We separated.

 That first cold winter I survived thanks to my friend and her two dogs. I moved into a rented little house in the countryside near Norrtälje, with nothing but the most essential, my laptop and an internet connection. No Visa-card (cut it halves to prevent myself from gambling), no car, no TV – just me and my addiction. And my depression. And my tries to get society to help me quit gambling. I did not succeed in the latter.

 I started writing in stead. On my blog, beskrivarblogg.wordpress.com. and on the writer´s site 1av3.se, where I also write a chronicle every Thursday. No secrets any more, I openly write about my addiction and my fight to recover. My way of writing is appreciated, by others than my family and friends.

 Now I have not gambled for almost two years. I am still an addict. Everytime the urge hits me, I write. The texts that I now want to make into both a printed conventional book and an e-book. In Swedish and in English.

 Noone knows how many of us gambling addicts that are there, everywhere. But I do know that I am not alone. I want to show that you can begin your new life also at 70. I want to stress that there is a life without being a loser. Also if you have lost it all.

 I am not a loser any more, my much loved partner is back in my life, part-time. And strangely enough I do not want all not to have happened – I owe my writing to my netgambling!

 If you don´t have money to contribute, please spread the word. And talk to people you know about gambling addiction, talking helps revealing the secrets.

 Any money raised this way will be spent on getting computer program for creating the e-book, in Swedish and in English. And, if there is enough money, on printing the book, maybe POD. No money goes to gambling.

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
Just the Facts

For more than twenty years, KJ McLean has felt a strong need for a centre for creative writers in Saint John, New Brunswick -- a small city on the Atlantic coast of Canada.  Her vision is of a place where creative writing is celebrated and encouraged, where writers of all ages and experience levels can gather to learn, network share resources, and -- of course -- to write!

After being a substitute teacher for more than ten years, and teaching creative writing classes to adults, KJ is passionate about helping people -- particularly young people -- find their voices and tell their stories.

Saint John is a city that has been struggling economically in recent years.  Among other plans, KJ wants Word Collective Ink Ltd. to provide opportunities and encouragement for children and teens in priority neighbourhoods to express themselves.  Related to this, the planned location for Word Collective Ink Ltd. was chosen not only to be central and easily accessible to all, but to also help revitalize a dated business area.

Word Collective Ink Ltd. is a much-needed resource centre to foster cultural, societal and economic growth in Saint John -- and KJ has the passion, knowledge and dedication to make it happen.

What We Need

We are confident that we can cover our monthly operational costs via class fees and office rentals.  What is holding us back from opening our doors is our start-up costs.

We specifically need funding for:

  • incorporation and registration
  • furniture for the offices (desks, chairs, bulletin boards)
  • furniture for the gathering/cafe area (tables and chairs)
  • electronic equipment (projector, laser printer, computer)
  • phone and Internet activation
  • upgrading the security system
  • paint and other "sprucing up" materials
  • extra month's rent (deposit)
  • insurance
  • other start-up costs

Any funding above and beyond our start-up requirements will go into the bank account as a "buffer."  If we don't reach our goal, we will put the money in the Word Collective bank account until we have accumulated enough to launch.

How We'll Thank You

We have four levels of funding perks to show you our appreciation!  All sponsors will receive a personal thank you email from KJ and a printable certificate of appreciation suitable for framing.  Other goodies include Word Collective USB flash drives, tote bags and t-shirts, and contributors of $1000 will have the name of their choice engraved on a Wall of Fame plaque that will be on permanent display at Word Collective Ink Ltd.

You CAN Make a Difference!

By funding Word Collective's campaign, you will be directly encouraging new literary talent and changing people's lives.  Besides helping adults who have always wanted to write stories, Word Collective Ink Ltd. will also be a beacon to young people who are looking for ways to express themselves -- to deal with and share their emotions and experiences in a positive way.  Word Collective is not simply about putting words on a page -- it's about bringing people together, and breathing new life into a once-vibrant business area.  Great things happen when people come together and inspire one another -- and you can help set this chain reaction in motion!

Please Help Spread the Word

Even if you are unable to make a donation to our campaign, we would greatly appreciate your sharing our campaign with your Facebook friends and Twitter followers.

Visit us at www.wordcollective.ca

story:
Note: if you experience problems donating using the Safari browser, please try using Firefox or another browser. 

Since 2007, The Arts Fuse has been covering arts and culture in Greater Boston and New England, including dance, film, food, literature, music, television, theater, video games, and visual arts.


In July 2014, we celebrate our 7th birthday and we're raising funds to help us pay our writers and critics and keep growing! 


We want to keep producing great free editorial coverage for Greater Boston and beyond, along with increasing our marketing activities so our readership keeps growing. Artsfuse.org currently gets 35,000 visits per month...and the more people who discover us, the more we hear how much they love what we are doing! 

Since The Arts Fuse is a web-only arts magazine, we have no overhead costs: no offices or desks, satellite dishes or printing presses or delivery trucks, so your donations will go directly to the writers themselves!

After we raise $10,000, we will use the funds to:

• keep paying our writers and critics for their invaluable work over the next six months
• run our second taxi-top advertising campaign in Fall 2014
• hire a street team to post Arts Fuse flyers all over Boston, Cambridge, Brookline, and Somerville

Since The Arts Fuse began publishing in July 2007, it has dramatically increased editorial coverage of the arts and culture across Greater Boston with in-depth criticism, previews, interviews, and commentary. 

In reaction to the declining arts coverage in newspapers, magazines, radio, and television, Editor-in-Chief Bill Marx started The Arts Fuse as a non-profit organization that could experiment with professional online arts criticism, looking at new and innovative ways to use the online platforms to evolve the conversation and bring together critics, readers, and artists. 

Now, with more than 2,500 articles published, The Arts Fuse is providing the next-generation platform for thousands of arts and culture consumers in the US as well as overseas, helping increase awareness of Greater Boston as a cultural hub and destination. 

The Arts Fuse now has more than 60 contributing writers, critics, and editors in Greater Boston and beyond. During our 7th anniversary party, as an extra incentive, you can donate and get to meet or see a show, concert, or exhibit with one of our writers and critics!  

Are you an artist that wants to attend an arts event and see and hear how an arts critic thinks and approaches their craft? Want to pick their brain about the process of arts criticism? Now's your chance...

For more than two decades, Bill Marx wrote about arts and culture for print, broadcast, and online media outlets including WBUR, WGBH, NPR, The Boston Globe, The Boston Phoenix, Washington Post Book World, the Nation, the Boston Review, The Los Angeles Times, the Columbia Journalism Review, and The Village Voice. Bill won United Press International and Associated Press awards for his radio reviews of Boston theater. He has been a finalist for the National Book Critics Circle Reviewer’s Citation three times.

==

Harvey Blume is an author ("Ota Benga: The Pygmy At The Zoo") who has published essays, reviews, and interviews widely in The New York Times, The Boston Globe, Agni, The American Prospect, and The Forward, among others. His blog in progress, which will archive that material and be a platform for the new, is here. He contributes regularly to The Arts Fuse and wants to help it continue to grow into a critical voice to be reckoned with.

==

An urban designer, Mark Favermann has been deeply involved in branding, enhancing, and making more accessible parts of cities, sports venues, and key institutions through his firm Favermann Design. Also an award-winning public artist, he creates functional public art as civic design. Mark created the Looks of the 1996 Centennial Olympic Games in Atlanta, the 1999 Ryder Cup Matches in Brookline, MA, and the 2000 NCAA Final Four in Indianapolis. The designer of the renovated Coolidge Corner Theatre, he has been a design consultant to the Red Sox since 2002. 

==

Matt Hanson is a critic for The Arts Fuse living outside Boston. His writing has appeared in The Millions, 3QuarksDaily, and Flak Magazine, where he was a staff writer. He blogs about movies and culture for LoveMoneyClothes. His poetry chapbook was published by Rhinologic Press.

==

Tim Jackson is an assistant professor at the New England Institute of Art in the Digital Film and Video Department. His music career in Boston began in the 1970s and includes some 20 groups, many recordings, national and international tours, and contributions to film soundtracks. He studied theater and English as an undergraduate and has also has worked helter skelter as an actor and member of SAG and AFTRA since the 1980s. He has directed a trio of documentaries: Chaos and Order: Making American Theater about the American Repertory Theater, and Radical Jesters, which profiles the practices of 11 interventionist artists and agit-prop performance groups. His third documentary, When Things Go Wrong, about the Boston singer/songwriter Robin Lane, with whom he has worked for 30 years, has just been completed. You can read more of his work on his blog.

==

Milo Miles has reviewed world-music and American-roots music for “Fresh Air with Terry Gross” on NPR since 1989. He is a former music editor of The Boston Phoenix. Milo is a contributing writer for Rolling Stone magazine and has also written about music for The Village Voice and The New York Times. His blog about pop culture and more is Miles To Go. 

==


Susan Miron, a harpist, has been a book reviewer for over 20 years for a large variety of literary publications and newspapers. Her fields of expertise were East and Central European, Irish, and Israeli literature. Susan covers classical music for The Arts Fuse and The Boston Musical Intelligencer. She is part of the Celtic harp and storytelling duo A Bard’s Feast with renowned storyteller Norah Dooley and plays the Celtic harp at the Cancer Center at Newton Wellesley Hospital.

==

Gerald Peary is a professor at Suffolk University, Boston, curator of the Boston University Cinematheque, and the general editor of the “Conversations with Filmmakers” series from the University Press of Mississippi. A critic for the late Boston Phoenix, he is the author of 9 books on cinema, writer-director of the documentary For the Love of Movies: the Story of American Film Criticism, and a featured actor in the 2013 independent narrative Computer Chess.

==

Glenn Rifkin is a veteran journalist and author who has covered business for many publications including The New York Times for more than 25 years. Among his books are Radical Marketing and The Ultimate Entrepreneur. His efforts as an arts critic and food writer represent a new and exciting direction.

==


Over the past 15 years Noah Schaffer has written about otherwise unheralded musicians from the worlds of gospel, jazz, blues, Latin, African, reggae, Middle Eastern music, klezmer, polka and far beyond. He has won over ten awards from the New England Newspaper and Press Association.

==


Roberta Silman is the author of a story collection, Blood Relations, now available as an ebook, three novels, Boundaries, The Dream Dredger, and Beginning the World Again, and a children’s book, Somebody Else’s Child. A recipient of Guggenheim and National Endowment for the Arts Fellowships, she has published reviews in The New York Times and The Boston Globe. 

==

Ian Thal is a performer and theatre educator specializing in mime, commedia dell’arte, and puppetry and has been known to act on Boston area stages from time to time, sometimes with Teatro delle Maschere, and on occasion served on productions as a puppetry choreographer or dramaturg. He has performed his one-man show, Arlecchino Am Ravenous, in numerous venues in Massachusetts and Rhode Island, and is currently working on his second full length play; his first, though as-of-yet unproduced, was picketed by a Hamas supporter during a staged reading. Formally the community editor at The Jewish Advocate, he blogs irregularly at The Journals of Ian Thal, and writes the “Nothing But Trouble” column forThe Clyde Fitch Report.


==

Peter Walsh has worked for the Harvard Art Museums, the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, Wellesley College, The Metropolitan Museum of Art, Dartmouth College, and the Boston Athenaeum, among other institutions. His reviews and articles on the visual arts have appeared in numerous publications and he has lectured widely in the United States and Europe. He has an international reputation as a scholar of museum studies and the history and theory of media.

See a full list of Arts Fuse contributors on Wikipedia .

These perks are sure to go fast, so make your donation today...and keep The Arts Fuse burning bright!

Her fields of expertise were East and Central European, Irish, and Israeli literature. Susan covers classical music for The Arts Fuse and The Boston Musical Intelligencer. She is part of the Celtic harp and storytelling duo A Bard’s Feast with renowned storyteller Norah Dooley and plays the Celtic harp at the Cancer Center at Newton Wellesley Hospital.==Gerald Peary is a professor at Suffolk University, Boston, curator of the Boston University Cinematheque, and the general editor of the “Conversations with Filmmakers” series from the University Press of Mississippi. A critic for the late Boston Phoenix, he is the author of 9 books on cinema, writer-director of the documentary For the Love of Movies: the Story of American Film Criticism, and a featured actor in the 2013 independent narrative Computer Chess.==Glenn Rifkin is a veteran journalist and author who has covered business for many publications including The New York Times for more than 25 years. Among his books are Radical Marketing and The Ultimate Entrepreneur. His efforts as an arts critic and food writer represent a new and exciting direction.==Over the past 15 years Noah Schaffer has written about otherwise unheralded musicians from the worlds of gospel, jazz, blues, Latin, African, reggae, Middle Eastern music, klezmer, polka and far beyond. He has won over ten awards from the New England Newspaper and Press Association.==
Roberta Silman is the author of a story collection, Blood Relations, now available as an ebook, three novels, Boundaries, The Dream Dredger, and Beginning the World Again, and a children’s book, Somebody Else’s Child. A recipient of Guggenheim and National Endowment for the Arts Fellowships, she has published reviews in The New York Times and The Boston Globe. ==Ian Thal is a performer and theatre educator specializing in mime, commedia dell’arte, and puppetry and has been known to act on Boston area stages from time to time, sometimes with Teatro delle Maschere, and on occasion served on productions as a puppetry choreographer or dramaturg. He has performed his one-man show, Arlecchino Am Ravenous, in numerous venues in Massachusetts and Rhode Island, and is currently working on his second full length play; his first, though as-of-yet unproduced, was picketed by a Hamas supporter during a staged reading. Formally the community editor at The Jewish Advocate, he blogs irregularly at The Journals of Ian Thal, and writes the “Nothing But Trouble” column forThe Clyde Fitch Report.==
Peter Walsh has worked for the Harvard Art Museums, the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, Wellesley College, The Metropolitan Museum of Art, Dartmouth College, and the Boston Athenaeum, among other institutions. His reviews and articles on the visual arts have appeared in numerous publications and he has lectured widely in the United States and Europe. He has an international reputation as a scholar of museum studies and the history and theory of media.See a full list of Arts Fuse contributors on Wikipedia .These perks are sure to go fast, so make your donation today...and keep The Arts Fuse burning bright!

story:
Bit of a Hiccup

We've had some problems with communication and availability and will no longer be illustrating the collection. It is still available for pre-order, and we will still honor the pledges as they stand so far, but the trading cards are out of the running. For those of you who have already pre-ordered at the $30 level, we will be refunding you $5 to compensate for that fact.  

The Horror of the Holidays

Come join us in a world where your fun, lovable holiday icons are transformed into twisted little horror fables for you to enjoy. Between presidents becoming zombies, Uncle Sam becoming a vampire, Cupid represented as hellspawn bent on ruining love, and many more, this collection is a hellish good time. So, come join us and find out for yourself what evil stalks the world during your favorite holiday.

This collection has been curated by D. A. DeCuzzi and award winning book designer Rebecca A. Demarest is getting the manuscript prepped and ready for publication, with books scheduled to go out to contributors before Thanksgiving.

The Contents

All told, we have 26 horrifying works to titillate and delight your gorier senses.

  • “New Year, New Life, New Beginning” by Paul Adams (New Year’s Day)

  • “Bloodhog Day” by John Reti (Groundhog Day)

  • “The Edge of Menace” by Paul Loh (Lunar New Year)

  • “Cupid’s Delight” by Kelsy Tiffany (Valentine’s Day)

  • “Valentine Pokemon” by Rita Dinis (Mardi Gras)

  • “The Hag Stone” by Michelle Renee Lane (Valentine's Day/Lupercalia)

  • “Dead Presidents” by Amy Frischmann (Presidents Day)

  • “Beware the Ides of March” by Kerry E.B. Black (Ides of March)

  • “Afterbirth” by Michael D. Kanoy and Abbey Sweeny (Saint Patrick’s Day)

  • “Skeleton Boy” by D. A. DeCuzzi (Easter)

  • “Memorial Day” by Samie Sands (Memorial Day)

  • “O Canada Day” by Kerry E.B. Black (Canada Day)

  • “I Want You” by Amy Frischmann (Fourth of July)

  • “Good Brothers” by Michael D. Kanoy (Hungry Ghost Month - China)

  • “Once Upon a Hallow’s Eve” by D. A. DeCuzzi (Halloween)

  • “The Illinois” by Ryan Edel (Columbus Day)

  • “Opposite Day” by Matthew Stitt (Random Declared Opposite Day!)

  • “Perdidito Dia de los Muertos” by Kerry E.B. Black (Day of the Dead)

  • “The Haunted House” by D. A. DeCuzzi (Halloween)

  • “The Queen is in Love” by Michael D. Kanoy (Halloween)

  • “Sadie Hawkins Day” by Kerry E.B. Black (Sadie Hawkins Day)

  • “Thanksgiving” by Delcie McCulloch (Thanksgiving)

  • “Farmer’s Daughter” by Michael D. Kanoy (Thanksgiving)

  • “Brains like Figgy Pudding” by Sean Hoade (Christmas)

  • “The Christmas Gnome” by Tony Dews (Christmas)

  • “Nice or Naughty” by Thomas H. Brand (Christmas)

What You Get

  • $1 ~ Apprentice of Minor Inconveniences: A heartfelt thank you and a mention in the acknowledgments of the book.

  • $5 ~ Practitioner of Perversions: A thank you in the acknowledgments and a postcard of the cover of the collection.

  • $25 ~ Adept of Atrocities: A thank you in the acknowledgments, a postcard of the cover, and a preordered paperback copy of the collection.

  • $30 ~ Journeyman of Depravity: This level is no longer available.

Stretch Goals

If we make it past our initial goal, we have some fun prizes set up for all of you:

  • $1,000 ~ If we make it to our first goal, everyone who contributes will get a free ebook of the collection, regardless of backer level!

  • $2,000 ~ If we make it to this goal, not only will we be able to better compensate our authors, it will get everyone another bonus story!

  • Every $1,000 after this that we earn will garner our supporters an extra story in their collection!

Now, some of you are probably wondering what we can do if we earn more money than we say we need. Here’s what we will do:

  • $3300 ~ If we make it to here, we’ll actually be able to pay everyone up front for all of their work instead of relying on royalties, which means everyone gets paid sooner, yay!

  • $4000 ~ We can pay our contributors a competitive, professional grade rate for their work. How exciting would that be!

  • $5000 ~ We can start putting together another collection of horror stories for you to enjoy!

Risks & Challenges

There are risks with any project, but the good news is, all of the stories have already been written. In fact, they’re almost entirely edited as well. All we have left to do is get the artwork from the Illustrator (he’s already part way through!) and get the book all put together. We have a top-notch, award winning book designer working on that right now, and we’ll share updates on the art and the design as the campaign goes on!

Now, there’s always the possibility of delays in printing and the like, but we’re mitigating those as much as possible by doing things like going with print on demand for publication, which allows for a much faster turn-around and fewer scheduling problems.

Other Ways You Can Help

We know that the Elder Gods have not blessed everyone with an abundance of earthly riches, so if you like our campaign and would like to see it succeed, please use the share buttons to pass the word along to other horror lovers. And, don’t forget, even if you donate a single dollar, you will most likely get a free ebook copy of the whole collection, and possibly a few other stories as well!

story:
En español abajo...

VOLTAGE VARIATIONS

Conversations with Mexican sound artists and electronic musicians

A book project by Carlos  Prieto Acevedo

 

VOLTAGE VARIATIONS is an encyclopedic project based on critical interpretations of sound art, electronic and electro-acoustic music in Mexico. Published in three volumes, this is a series of 25 interviews, an extensive glossary of terms dealing with the aesthetics of sound, audio technologies, and musical genres; as well as institutional monographs and biographies. The books will also contain very rich visual documentation in the form of facsimiles and other images, as well as three downloadable compilations of music. This project, made up of detailed research and interviews done over the last five years, brings together the testimonies of composers, DJs, sound engineers, electronic music producers and sound artists, with the aim of creating an intersection of ideas about the transformations in the cultural and artistic identity in Mexico, within the amorphous territory of sound and technology.  In this collection the reader will find a series of conversations with a very diverse group of artists, from the creators of the Nortec movement, to the pioneers of radio, to electro-acoustic composers who have driven experimentation within academic circles, to the first auto-didactics who have interlaced and mixed musical genres, to DJs who have shaped the vast experience of electronic dance music, and the most recent attempts that sound art has made to translate our ways of experiencing the world.

 

ARTISTS AND MUSICIANS IN THE COLLECTION :

VOLUME 1. Antonio Russek · Roberto Morales Manzanares · (Bostich) Ramón Amescua · Mario de Vega · Walter Schmidt · (Murcof) Fernando Corona Murillo · Rodolfo Sánchez Alvarado· Manuel Rocha Iturbide · Héctor Quintanar.

VOLUME 2. Rodrigo Sigal · Plug (Cristian Cárdenas) · Álvaro Ruiz · Rogelio Sosa · DJ Chrysler (Luis Carlos Gómez) · Fax (Rubén Alonso Tamayo) · Gonzalo Macías ·Gabriela Ortíz.

VOLUME 3. Duopandamix · Ángel Sánchez Borges · Angélica Castelló · Guillermo Galindo · Israel Martínez · Javier Álvarez · Manrico Montero · Pepe Mogt


 

 ^/  WHERE WE ARE AT AND WHY WE NEED FUNDING 

This project has been funded so far by a grant from the FONCA (National Cultural Fund) with in-kind services and institutional support.  We are ready to go to print!  And we need your help to make it through the last stretch.

Opting for collaborations with independent artists (photographer, designer, publisher) in order to keep the most freedom in terms of content, the formal aspects of the collection also reflect the ideas and methods of those artists and musicians that the book is about.  We have organized the project (the conversations with the 25 artists, the archival material and the extensive glossary) into 3 volumes, which will be released one after the other… but we need to reach our funding goal to avoid any delays!

As we write this, the editorial team at Deleátur is copy-editing, and the graphic design team is conforming the text, preparing each volume to go to the printers.  Now, we just need to complete our finances to be able to print in the highest quality and most environmentally sound materials, while staying true to our aesthetic and the quality we strive for.

All of the 25 artists have been incredible collaborators and one of the main goals of the book is to bring them more to the public eye, in Mexico and abroad.  We already have plans to translate the book into English, but all of this depends on the way we can accomplish this first release.

With your help, we can go to print on the three volumes, prepare our promotional campaign, and organize the special events and concerts that are already being planned and scheduled.  In fact, we have a release date of mid-May, with a whole series of events already planned from then until December 2013, in collaboration with important music festivals, art centers, and book fairs.  From Mexico City, to Monterrey, to Tijuana, to New York… it is all in our calendar… All we need now is to get the book and all the promotional materials (posters, flyers, etc) made and ready for release.  

Please help with any size contributions, and PLEASE SPREAD THE WORD!!

 

 

^/  WHO ARE WE ?

AUTHOR : Carlos Prieto Acevedo (b. 1973, Mexico City)   Carlos studied in the Philosophy Department at the Autonomous University of Mexico (UNAM) and has specialized his work and research in Aesthetic Theory. He has worked in music and art criticism and journalism, writing for magazines, fanzines, and other publications since 1995. He was artistic programmer and producer for festivals and events revolving around electronic music, most notably MUTEK-Mexico, where he worked from 2003 to 2008. Since 2009, Carlos writes the program notes and texts for the experimental music festivals, RADAR and AURAL in Mexico City. In 2008 he was artistic director of a public art project called Peatonal, Encounters with Art and Politics, under the auspices of the Mexico City government. Carlos also produces radio programs, mostly with RADIO UNAM, where his last program was “1978: The year we lived in fear”. In 2012, Carlos was invited to produce a series of sound pieces to install in the 20th Century halls of the MUNAL (Museum of National Art) as part of a curated program called “Contemporary Dialogues”. This series of sound art pieces that he made were called “Sonoral Intermitencies of Modernity” and were installed along side pieces by José Clemente Orozco, Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera among other painters. For the last few years, Carlos has been researching and writing the book project, VOLTAGE VARIATIONS, which are compiled of dialogues with 25 Mexican electronic musicians, old and young. The book, made up of three volumes, will be released in May and October 2013, accompained by a series of concerts. The book was developed with the support of the FONCA. Since 2009, Carlos is a full time professor at the Universidad del Claustro de Sor Juana, where he teaches a seminar on the philosophy of communication. /

http://interregno.org     http://radiogramas.org    http://radio1978.org/

 

PHOTOGRAPHER : Luis Mendez (b. 1976, Mexico)  Freelance photographer at 82Photo / http://www.ochentaydos.com

GRAPHIC DESIGNER : Laura Balboa (b. 1979, Mexico)   She studied in visual arts at the School of Painting, Sculpture and Engraving "La Esmeralda" of the National Center for the Arts in Mexico and graphic design at the School of Higher Studies Acatlán affiliated to the National Autonomous University of Mexico.  Some of her teaching practices include: design and technology workshops for children, graphic design and communication strategies for artists and designers, workshops to understand our relation to technology and objects of everyday life and visual arts activities for mentally ill inmates.  /  http://www.laurabalboa.com

DELEATUR ESTUDIO / Publishing services :  Deleátur is an independent studio specializing in editorial services and consulting that promote and develop the investigation, professional training and the creativity in publishing. / http://www.deleatur.com.mx

 

 

_________

VARIACIÓN DE VOLTAJE

Conversaciones con artistas sonoros y músicos electrónicos mexicanos

 Un proyecto de Carlos Prieto Acevedo

 

VARIACIÓN DE VOLTAJE es un proyecto enciclopédico de divulgación e interpretación crítica del arte sonoro y la música electrónica y electroacústica mexicana.  Editado en 3 tomos, está conformado por 25 entrevistas, un extenso glosario de términos sobre estética del sonido, tecnología de audio, géneros musicales, monografías institucionales y biografías. Incluye también una rica documentación facsimilar y gráfica, así como tres discos descargables de audio. El proyecto, realizado mediante una investigación documental y entrevistas con diversos creadores mexicanos a lo largo de 5 años, incorpora los testimonios de compositores, DJ's, ingenieros de audio, productores de música electrónica y artistas sonoros, con la intención de integrar en un documento el paisaje de alteraciones a la identidad artística y cultural mexicana desde el territorio amorfo de la tecnología y el sonido.  En este compendio se ponen a disposición del lector una serie de conversaciones con artistas tan diversos como los creadores del movimiento Nortec, los pioneros de la radio, los compositores electroacústicos que impulsaron la experimentación desde los espacios académicos, los primeros autodidactas en cruzar y entrelazar categorías y géneros musicales, los DJ's que forjaron la experiencia masiva de la electrónica de baile, hasta las tentativas más recientes del arte sonoro por desbordar nuestras formas de experimentar el mundo.

 

ARTISTAS Y MUSICOS EN LA COLECCIÓN  :

VOLUMEN 1. Antonio Russek · Roberto Morales Manzanares · (Bostich) Ramón Amescua · Mario de Vega · Walter Schmidt · (Murcof) Fernando Corona Murillo · Rodolfo Sánchez Alvarado· Manuel Rocha Iturbide · Héctor Quintanar.

VOLUMEN 2. Rodrigo Sigal · Plug (Cristian Cárdenas) · Álvaro Ruiz · Rogelio Sosa · DJ Chrysler (Luis Carlos Gómez) · Fax (Rubén Alonso Tamayo) · Gonzalo Macías ·Gabriela Ortíz.

VOLUMEN 3. Duopandamix · Ángel Sánchez Borges · Angélica Castelló · Guillermo Galindo · Israel Martínez · Javier Álvarez · Manrico Montero · Pepe Mogt

 

 

^/  ¿ DÓNDE NOS ENCONTRAMOS Y PORQUÉ NECESITAMOS TU AYUDA?

Este proyecto fue auspiciado en un inicio, cuando era muchísimo más pequeño y sencillo, por el programa de co-inversiones del FONCA, y se ha continuado (y ampliado gigantescamente) gracias al respaldo de otras instituciones, iniciativas independientes, y fundamentalmente a la generosidad de muchos individuos. ¡Estamos listos para entrar a la imprenta! Justo por eso necesitamos tu apoyo para finalizar la etapa de producción, ese último paso indispensable para que el proyecto llegue a las manos de todos los que han hecho de la electricidad y el sonido parte de su vida, o a los que se interesan acercarse a este fenómeno del arte sonoro y la música electrónica.

La colaboración y el trabajo de artistas independientes en el proyecto (los editores, el fotógrafo, la artista gráfica), nos permitió mantener una gran libertad en términos de contenido y en la forma en que se organiza la información y la rica documentación. Ya que los aspectos formales de la colección y de cada uno de los libros reproduce de alguna manera los métodos e ideas de los propios artistas sonoros y músicos de los que trata el proyecto. Consta de 25 amplias conversaciones, un abundante material facsimilar y gráfico, y un extenso glosario, ha sido organizado en 3 volúmenes que saldrán consecutivamente uno después del otro durante el año... ¡pero aún necesitamos alcanzar nuestro monto a recaudar para evitar cualquier retraso!

Mientras tú lees esto, el equipo editorial del estudio Deleátur está preparando cada volumen para entrara a impresión: revisando minuciosamente cada una de las páginas y formando en un extraordinario diseño editorial el inmenso contendido; y la diseñadora está retocando los materiales gráficos. Sólo necesitamos completar nuestros presupuestos de producción y garantizar con ello la más alta calidad en los materiales y procesos de impresión y en las plataformas digitales en línea de donde podrás descargar las antologías de música que acompañan éste titánico compendio.

Los 25 creadores han sido increíblemente generosos con el proyecto, y uno de los principales objetivos es darle una mayor visibilidad a su trabajo en México y en el contexto internacional. Incluso ya se tiene planeada su traducción al inglés, pero todo depende de la manera en que logremos imprimir el primero.

Con tu apoyo y aportaciones podremos entrar a la imprenta con los 3 volúmenes, preparar nuestra campaña promocional y la gira de presentaciones, conciertos y eventos especiales que incluso ya están en la agenda y que realizaremos en colaboración con importantes festivales, ferias y centros artísticos. Nuestra fecha oficial de presentación ya está programada para la segunda semana de mayo, con un evento fuera de serie en el festival Aural; y continuamos hasta diciembre con más actividades y descargas sonoras, electrizando el año entero. Desde el Distrito Federal hasta Monterrey, Tijuana, Guadalajara y Nueva York ¡ya está todo calendarizado! lo único que nos falta es imprimir el libro y los materiales de promoción (carteles, programas de mano, fyers etcétera), ¡y tenerlos listos para su lanzamiento!

Ayúdanos con cualquier tipo de contribución, no importa el tamaño... Y POR FAVOR ¡DIFUNDELO! 

 

 ^/   ¿ QUIENES SOMOS ?

AUTOR : Carlos Prieto Acevedo (cd. de México, 1973)  Cursó estudios de licenciatura en filosofía en la FFYL de la UNAM, concentrando sus intereses en la teoría estética. Incursiona en el periodismo y la crítica musical en suplementos, revistas, fanzines y fundando publicaciones desde 1995 hasta la fecha. Fue programador artístico, director de información y productor de eventos, festivales y encuentros relacionados con la música electrónica en México desde fines de los años 90, entre ellos MUTEK - México durante el período 2003-2008. Ha dedicado parte de su trabajo filosófico a investigar la relación entre el sonido y lo social, y en las posibilidades del medio radiofónico creando proyectos digitales y analógicos, series documentales, e incluso tentativas de señal analógica para radios comunitarias. Desde 2009 colabora en la redacción de los programas de mano de electrónica experimental del festival Radar y luego en Aural. En 2008 fue director artístico del proyecto de arte público Peatonal, Encuentros de Arte y Política, auspiciado por el GDF. Produjo en 2010 la serie radiofónica "1978, el año que vivimos en peligro", transmitida por Radio UNAM. Realizó en 2012 la intervención sonora para la sala siglo XX del Museo Nacional de Arte, Intermitencias Sonoras de la Modernidad, en el marco Diálogos Contemporáneos. Actualmente prepara un ciclo de conciertos que acompañará la presentación de su trabajo de investigación "Variación de Voltaje", un compendio en 3 tomos sobre la historia de la música electrónica y electroacústica mexicana, que realiza desde 2008 gracias a una beca del FONCA, y que se lanzará este año. Desde 2009 es profesor de tiempo completo en la Universidad del Claustro de Sor Juana, en donde imparte el seminario de filosofía de la comunicación. /

http://interregno.org     http://radiogramas.org    http://radio1978.org/

 

FOTÓGRAFO : Luis Mendez (b. 1976, Mexico)  Freelance photographer at 82Photo /  http://www.ochentaydos.com

DISEÑADORA : Laura Balboa (b. 1979, Mexico)  Realizó estudios en artes visuales en la Escuela de Pintura, Escultura y Grabado "La Esmeralda" y de diseño gráfico en la Facultad de Estudios Superiores Acatlán afiliada a la Universidad Autónoma de México. Ha impartido cursos de arte y tecnología para niños, cursos de diseño y comunicación gráfica, talleres sobre tecnología e internet en la vida diaria y cursos de artes visuales para enfermos psiquiátricos en reclusión. / http://www.laurabalboa.com

DELEATUR ESTUDIO / Taller de edición : Deleátur es un estudio de asesoría y de servicios editoriales que promueve, asimismo, la investigación, la formación profesional y la creatividad editorial. / http://www.deleatur.com.mx
